questions.question: A material shows a high value of H/E. This primarily indicates:

explanations.a: Incorrect: High plastic deformation corresponds to low H/E.
explanations.b: Correct: High H/E indicates greater elastic recovery and resistance to crack initiation.
explanations.c: Incorrect: H/E is unrelated to thermal properties.
explanations.d: Incorrect: H/E has no relation to surface roughness.

questions.question: If the unloading stiffness S increases while all other parameters remain constant, the calculated modulus will:

explanations.a: Incorrect: Higher stiffness means higher modulus.
explanations.b: Correct: E<sub>r</sub> ∝ S. Higher stiffness corresponds to higher elastic modulus, meaning the material is stiffer and offers greater resistance to elastic deformation.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Modulus cannot become zero when there is measurable stiffness.

questions.question: Two materials have the same hardness. Material A has lower modulus than Material B. Which will likely show better wear resistance?

explanations.a: Correct: Lower modulus indicates higher  H/E and H³/E², Material A will exhibit greater elastic recovery and smaller plastic zones, leading to improved wear resistance.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Higher modulus leads to lower elastic recovery, making it more prone to wear.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Their wear resistance will differ based on modulus.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Prediction is possible from H/E and H³/E² ratios.

questions.question: Which parameter is most directly related to resistance against plastic ploughing during sliding wear?

explanations.a: Incorrect: Modulus alone does not determine ploughing resistance.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Load is only experimental input, not a material property.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Contact depth is an indentation geometry parameter.
explanations.d: Correct: H³/E² quantifies resistance to plastic deformation and plastic zone size. Higher values reduce ploughing and debris formation, directly lowering wear.
